history.content:
For 61B, it's fine if you don't have any Java experience, as long as you're doing well with Python it's not too bad to pick up. The projects will be time consuming still, so expect maybe 7-10 hours.

For 126 it really depends on how well you do on the probability part of 70 that you haven't started yet, if you find that easy then 126 will still be challenging but not the hardest, if you find probability difficult 126 will be significantly more difficult. I'd call it 10-13 hours if you do well with 70 probability, more like 17-20 if you have trouble.

No clue about 127.

Overall sounds like a doable schedule given that you're surviving 4 techs rn.

children.subject: I have taken all of these classes (spread out over 3 semester, but I got As/A-s in all 3) and I want to make sure you understand the gravity of these classes. First of all to compare, I also took 3 out of the 4 classes you have in your schedule and got As in all of them, and I have taken 20 unit semesters multiple times. 126 and 127 are hard. Not in the way 54 and 70 are 61A are hard - where its a lot of work but relatively narrow and defined concepts that you can get a lot of practice on. 126 and 127 are classes that require, in my opinion, a significant amount of comfort with the basics of probability and linear algebra and even with that can take around 10-15 hours a week to truly complete the homework (which you need to do to have a solid enough understanding to do well on the tests). They cover a lot of content very quickly and they offer significantly less support than lower divisions. If you still want to take both and 61B, I highly recommend you make sure you have a good study group before going into all of these classes because you will probably need the support as things heat up. Also, make sure their midterms and finals don't fall on the same day/time, this happened to a few people I knew.

history.content:
I'm planning to take 61B, EECS 126 and 127, and a 1 unit decal/seminar this Spring. (13 units)

For context, I'm taking 61A, 70, Math 53 and 54 this sem and should get an A-/A in all of them, judging from my midterm results for 61A, 53, 54. (Current workload: 2.5 hours a week for Math 53, 5 hours a week each for 61A, 54 and 10 hours a week for 70)

So how much workload will the spring semester entail, assuming I have no Java/DS experience? Is it doable?
history.subject: Next sem schedule
